headline: Butternut and Apple Harvest Soup
description: This medley of Autumn vegetables combine to make a wonderfully warm and comforting soup. Pair this with crusty bread and a salad, and dinner is served!

video.description: Warm, Autumn comfort in every spoonful!
video.name: Butternut and Apple Harvest Soup

name: Butternut and Apple Harvest Soup
recipeIngredient: 2 large leeks (white and pale green parts only), chopped
1 Granny Smith apple, peeled, cored, and sliced 1/4-inch thick

recipeInstructions.text: Melt butter in a large pot over medium heat. Stir in leeks and onions, and cook until the onion softens and turns translucent, about 5 minutes. Add potato, squash, carrots, apple, and chicken stock. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until the vegetables are soft, about 20 minutes.

Carefully puree the soup in batches in a blender, or use a stick blender to puree the soup right in the pot. Once the soup has been pureed, return it to the pot and stir in wine and cream. Season with nutmeg, salt, and pepper; simmer gently for 5 minutes. Ladle into bowls and garnish with chopped chives.

review.reviewBody: Wonderful flavors. I like this the best of the butternut soup recipes I have tried.
Delicious! I followed the recipe as is. This is my new favorite fall soup!
Too much onion taste and not enough butternut squash. We did not like this.
Great recipe. I followed it as presented.
My favorite recipe. Creamy.
Classic autumn flavours! Easy to change up the vegetables to suit your tastes. This one is a keeper.
I used sour cream instead of heavy cream. Added some garlic and used ice wine in my mixture as well. Nice variety of ingredients in this one.
I loved this soup! Will definitely make again. I didn't use wine nor chives for garnish and added 1/2 butternut squash instead of measuring it out. Really really good!

I’ve been making this soup for years now and it’s always a hit. The one thing I do differently is to add the slightest dash of cayenne pepper. It gives it a little warmth in the back of the throat. My friends request this soup often and I’m happy to oblige.

I SO look forward to this soup every fall and winter. I love the flavoring combination from the apple and all the other vegetables. I do add good white wine and a good apple; I don't add the nutmeg. And it's my experience that if it sits in the refrigerator overnight the flavor is greatly enhanced the next day. But usually I can't wait and have to have a little cup right after it's made. Like with any soup, crusty bread on the side is a must.
Made this without the onion and leeks. Used 2 apples and 2 sweet potatoes in addition to the butternut squash. Used Apple spice and cinnamon instead of nutmeg. No wine.
Acidic! Lacked flavor.
I have made this recipe twice and love it! I did admit the cream and added extra nutmeg. I puréed half of the soup the first time I made it but prefer it more like a chunky vegetable soup style.
Great fall comfort food! I made the recipe as written and even my picky Husband liked it. Only thing is, we only use Greek Yogurt instead of sour cream. Personal preference.
My family thought it was delicious. The mix of veggies was super it tasted so good we didn't even add the cream at the end.
Really solid. Could use a little extra spice-- I added some salt and white pepper. Next time i might try a little clove as well.

This was a hit with my family. I did make some changes because I am doing WW and wanted to decrease my points as much as possible. I substituted I Can’t Believe It’s Not Butter for the regular butter, omitted the cream ( it really doesn’t need it), only added 1/2 of the Apple cider vinegar and 1/2 the pepper
One cup is plenty for a serving. This makes 10 servings at 1 point on WW green plan
Phenomenal! The hardest part was not having a sous chef to do all the prep work. I used Dry Riesling for the wine and Pumpkin Pie Spice in lieu of fresh Nutmeg and it was just perfect!! My M-F?

I made this soup for a board meeting in the fall and it was a big hit. Really nice flavor, I wouldn't change a thing. You could swap the potatoes for sweet potatoes or yams, but make sure to stick to the tart apples if you do.

We loved this soup! I substituted half and half for the light cream and used whatever apples I had on hand (gala). Next time I will make sure to get Granny Smith as I’m curious what that would do to the flavor profile. I also used a mix of chicken bone broth and vegetable broth (just what I had access to). It had at first delicate flavors, but became more complex the more I ate it. Will definitely try this again.
I only used onions (no leeks) and used two apples and did not add the wine and it was super yummy.

Twenty years ago my wife made this dish from the recipe provided in your printed magazine. It was a borrowed mag so she photocopied the page to take home to make. She was pregnant at the time. She made this wonderful soup only to find that she had an aversion to leeks and onions due to her pregnancy. She’s couldn’t eat it. However that photocopy has become somewhat tattered over the years from many references to it as we have enjoyed this soup over and over. I decided to look to see if I could find it online and here it is! Needless to say, it got printed again!
The carrots and apples overpowered the squash. We ate it because I hate to be wasteful but we didn’t truly enjoy it.

This was a delicious recipe. I made a slightly bigger batch as I didn't want to waste the butternut squash (added extra carrots etc.) I also added 1 stalk of celery and added a bit of turmeric, curry and cayenne pepper to give it some extra kick. Would definitely make this recipe again.

I can't give this five stars as I made some changes. I doubled the recipe for a large group but that made a LOT of soup - I could have kept the recipe as written. I used leeks and a combination of red and yellow onions due to what I had on hand. I also used Golden Hubbard and Ghost blue squash instead of butternut - again, what I had in my freezer. I used a very large Jonagold apple (sweeter than a Granny Smith). I also used coconut milk instead of cream. Everyone loved the soup and so did I. It is a keeper. Thanks.

I only had one large leek so I added a large sweet onion instead of the second leek in the recipe. I also added a teaspoon of fresh thyme while it was cooking. I frizzled some fresh sage and added a couple of pieces along with a drizzle of olive oil and a dollop of sour cream to each bowl to serve. Not only was this a dish of delish but it was also a soul warmer on a cold Fall day.

Made as written except I omitted the onion because my leek was so large, I used all of it. Didn't use wine either. I used by blender to puree the soup in batches as I do not have an emersion blender. By light cream , I assumed half and half and used that. I alway use "Better than Bullion" to make chicken broth. Also used frozen and defrosted butternut squash. Used a pink lady apple as that is what I had on hand. Very good soup and easy to make. Makes a ton, so I froze half of it.
Absolutely delicious. I wouldn't change a thing. I look forward to making this bisque every fall & winter. Buying the squash cubed from Costco saves time and is easier on arthritic hands.

I made this exactly as described. We all loved it. 
Perfect autumn dinner with salad and crusty bread.
This recipe is great as is. Last time I made it I used,apple cider instead of wine and left out the onion just used leeks. It's delicious!

Followed this exactly, except for subbing a 1/2 cup of half n half for the light cream, and didn't bother with the wine. It's very healthy and warming, and the blend of flavors is excellent. Also agree with others that it's even better the next day. I happen to have chives in my herb garden, and they really add to both the presentation and flavor. Great recipe, my thanks to the poster!
Turned out great,
Made it without the leeks because I didn't have any. I roasted the squash and carrots in advance. I would like the tart taste if the Apple to stand out more. I love the texture of this soup.
It was tasty and very enjoyable but I think small fresh beans would be good in it.
It was delicious. The hardest part was peeling the Butternut Squash, but well worth it!
Used vegetable broth instead of chicken and scallion instead of leeks.

Overall, really solid soup! I incorporated a few of the common review comments, left it largely unchanged. A nice meatless (although not vegetarian since I used homemade chicken stock), cozy fall soup. Nutritious and delicious! I'm definitely looking forward to lunches this week :)
I changed it around to use up some veggies that I had... but mostly stuck to the recipe - it was delish!
Best Butternut Squash I’ve ever had.

Felt it was too bland. The ratio of leeks and onion were too heavy so I added another apple and doubled the squash. 
It warmed the ribs, but I prefer more spice.
Hearty and delicious!

I didn't use a potato and I used my garden chives. I like it without the milk or cream. It is an easy base soup to try different things with. I really love using curry and ginger and another "try" that we liked was a pinch of nutmeg. I have made several large batches and plan on doing more to freeze while the squash is available. It was good with acorn squash too.

I didn't use a potato and I used my garden chives. I like it without the milk or cream. It is an easy base soup to try different things with. I really love using curry and ginger and another "try" that we liked was a pinch of nutmeg. I have made several large batches and plan on doing more to freeze while the squash is available. It was good with acorn squash too.
Followed the recipe exactly. It's a keeper
should teasted good
Loved this! Next time I’ll be experimenting with some of the spices mentioned in previous comments though. Even my husband liked it and wants to try different spice experiments of his own!

Made the soup. Read a few reviews before making it. I used sweet potato instead of potato. I added cloves ( only 1/8 tsp) and wish I hadn't. This soup was very bland as some said so I improvised. Added more nutmeg, brown sugar, more salt. Still wasn't right so I had an orange and juiced about 1/8th cup. Now you're talking flavor. Added a dollop of sour cream and handed over to my husband. He said it was better than the restaurant we frequent. I guess it was finally a "hit"!!!
Delicious - but too much work - but will probably make it again - will by peeled butternut squash/

I made this to the T. There was quite a bit of prep in comparison to some other squash soup recipes I have made. I put up squash every year, so I used already cooked and frozen squash which was a time saver. It is good, but I have some other favorites from allrecipes that I prefer over this one. Still a good soup!

I made this to the T. There was quite a bit of prep in comparison to some other squash soup recipes I have made. I put up squash every year, so I used already cooked and frozen squash which was a time saver. It is good, but I have some other favorites from allrecipes that I prefer over this one. Still a good soup!

I gave this recipe a 4, even though I thought it was just alright, because my husband loved it. I followed the instructions as written. Even though I salted and peppered it while cooking, I found that I needed to add more salt and pepper to my own individual serving --- it just needed extra flavoring. It was a very filling recipe served with a salad and rolls and great for a cold night meal.
Love butternut squash soup, but I added a bit of cinnamon to this for extra flavor, as well as extra cream. I think this recipe to made with far too many onions.

This is about the 4th or 5th time I've made this soup. It is delicious! The only thing I changed was that's I used vegetable stock instead of chicken (to make it vegetarian). I don't usually cook with leeks but I think that might be the key ingredient that takes this soup to the next level. My whole family, even the meat lovers, enjoyed this soup!

Amazing. My husband and son usually don’t go for anything but chili and stew. They loved this recipe. I personally loved it as well. It came out very smooth and creamy with just enough sweet. I didn’t have a nutmeg so I just threw in some apple pie spice. It was still really good. I will definitely be making this a lot
Didn't enjoy it unfortunately
This is a flavourful, delicious soup that the entire family loved. It will definitely become a regular menu item in our home. The recipe is perfect as it is, with no changes/additions.
I loved it! I did leave out the potato, and the leeks, and added a lot of onions and two apples! This soup is so delicious! You won’t be sorry, make it now!

I didn’t have chicken stock. My chicken broth worked well. I melted my blender during the purée process. Boo hoo.

I will make it again!! Delicious.

I really liked this, I used all frozen veggies including the butternut squash. I also added a small can of pumpkin and just eyeballed the nutmeg and cinnamon. I doubled this and made it in a crock pot. I also added frozen sweet potato, which I found at Walmart, because it was organic, it was more expensive, but you can find regular frozen sweet potato at Market Basket. Because all of the veggies were frozen it took eight hours on low and my crockpot is fairly new so it runs really good, your crockpot may vary in time, but you can just set it and forget it. I used a hand held blender to blend and it was a big hit!! It all went. I served this with grilled cheese sandwiches. You could serve this with just about any sandwich or fresh bread and a salad. Enjoy!!!!!
Pretty good!!!
I made it and I’d make it again. It was a bit sweet to me, I was light on the salt but that’s an easy fix.
Will not make this again
A little bland. 1/4 tsp Added cayenne, apple cider vinegar, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, more salt, and tarragon
Very good soup, would make again. I might add more butternut squash next time. I didn’t have nutmeg, so I used a pinch of cinnamon.

This soup is what my husband calls “very pleasant”....meaning please make more! I followed the recipe almost completely except that I used a sweet potato instead of a regular one and I used a Vidalia onion and some fresh minced garlic instead of the leeks. I also took the advice from some of the comments and roasted the butternut squash. A small handful of fresh herbs (thyme and sage) brought it home! Don’t let the purée step stop you! It is worth the effort for a truly elegant presentation.
This is my favorite butternut squash soup. Well worth all the prep!

Made this soup today. It is delicious. I didn't have leeks so used all onion. Also used Gala apple and a squash I had baked in the oven. Didn't have the wine so left it out. I always have fresh nutmeg so grated some in. It really added a nice flavor. Separated some and added light cream and some apple cider to that. The recipe is very good without cream and cider but I prefer it with. One other difference is I used vegetable stock so I can let my vegetarian friends try it. I will definitely make this again. Thank you for sharing.
We loved it - adding the wine adds more flavour, as well as the cream. We added a little extra spices. We make it every thanksgiving. It's become a family favourite.
Didn't have any wine open so left it out. It was delicious and I would make it again.
I used honey crisp apples touch of ginger. It was great will make .it agin and again

best soup ever! I make this every year at the start of fall and freeze it. It does take a while to make. I use sweet potato instead of regular. I also add a sprig of fresh rosemary while the butter and onions are cooking. Do yourself a favor and put all the ingredients like the apples, onions, carrots etc into a food processor before cooking. This soup can get quite chunky if you don't and that means more time in the blender later. I see a few people here don't add the cream. I personally like it much better wth the cream
Excellent soup for fall
A fantastic fall soup!!
This was SO good. My kids raved and raved about it and I look forward to making it every fall. I added an optional garnish of a sprinkle of crumbled goat cheese and chopped candied pecans. Oh my!
No changes. Yes will make again

This was delicious!!! I don't know how anyone can say it's bland because it was very flavorful. I made the recipe as written, except I didn't use a leek and I used milk instead of cream. I prefer a little thicker soup so I thickened it somewhat at the end. I precooked the squash for about 5 minutes in the microwave (pricking it several times), to make it easier to cut. I made a double batch and it used about 1/2 of my squash (so I cut the rest in cubes and froze to use the next time I make this). I made this last night and my house still smells SO good!
Great recipe. I added1/2 teaspoon of curry powder.
Awesome recipe, will make again! I used about 3/4 cups of white wine instead (used a chardonnay). Used a sweet yellow onion and omitted chives. Had no problems with blandness.

This soup was the disappointment of a lifetime. There was no point in putting any apples in there because their taste could not be detected whatsoever after they got mixed in with the rest of the vegetables. The finished product was a bland pool of mediocre-at-best slop. I'm not sure how they managed to ruin butternut squash, which was previously my favorite vegetable but now I'm not sure if I can trust it anymore. RIP

I thought this was soooo yummy. I was looking for something similar to Campbell's golden butternut squash soup in the box & oh man, this was like it but even better. It was so hearty & delicious & a lovely flavour. I used a sweet potato & half & half cream, & I also omitted the wine. Other than that, everything was the same. I will be making this A LOT in the colder months! Thank you!
Delicious! Just finishing up today.
I've been trying several butternut soup recipes lately in search of the one I'd make over and over again. This is it for me. Fantastic the way it is. Thanks, I love it!

Addicted to this soup!

I made this on a cold Autumn day. I did substitute the wine with apple cider and added lots of carrots. Everyone went crazy for it. It is addictive and healthy. Dropped some off to my sister and her family and for days they text me how much they loved the soup.
I added julienne green apple and gorgonzola on top of each serving....yummmmm

I did make some changes but I'm giving this 5 stars because it's a great base! I added 2 cloves of garlic, 2 tsp grated ginger, left out the wine, subbed out a few tbsp of sour cream for the cream since I didn't have any... so no it's not super close to the original but man is it ever good with a generous grind of sea salt and pepper!
This soup is amazing. I omit the dairy and there is no issues, can't even tell. Everyone in my family, including a 7 and 9 year old LOVE this soup.

I just finished making this soup! This was a very easy soup to make, which I like. Instead of potatoe I used sweet potatoe, i also substituted 3% milk instead of cream. In addition, I found the soup to lack a bit of flavour so I added allspice, ginger, cayenne pepper, and cinnamon.
I

I rarely review recipes because I read over the other reviews and use the suggestions. I don't feel you should rate something a 5 star when you have drastically changed the original recipe. But this one gets a true rating as I changed nothing. Followed the recipe as stated and we all loved it. We found the soup to be very filling so as suggested next time it will go with just a salad and some bread for a healthy and filling lunch or dinner.

Will make this soup often - loved it. I added a chopped gala apple after the soup was puréed, as we like small chunks mixed in. The apple softened up nicely since the soup was hot. For the spices I used allspice in place of the nutmeg & I also added cinnamon. Smells & tastes great!!!
I didn't have any leeks & used a different kind of apple. It was yummy!

Good basic recipe! Proportions of vegetables worked well. Followed previous reviews adding sweet potato (instead of a white potato) and 2 tablespoons of brown sugar, and omitting the white wine and light cream. Opted to season with cinnamon rather than nutmeg. Hearty, tasty, easy! Also used olive oil in lieu of butter.

I made this soup for my family last night and they loved it. Because of some dietary restrictions I changed it slightly by omitting the white wine and using full fat coconut milk instead of cream. It was divine. This will become a regular at our house.
I didn't have any wine and I'm avoiding dairy, so I left out the cream as well. It was still delicious and so easy to make.
This was a delicious recipe and so easy to make. I followed other readers' advice and used cider vinegar instead of wine (2 tbsps) and I used a tbsp of brown sugar to enhance the sweetness.
Outstanding, comfort soup. Only changes I made were apple cider in lieu of wine and pecan soy creamer rather than half and half. I topped it with roasted pumpkin seeds. Yum,

Wonderful! Made Vegan. Read the comments and made my own adjustments. I had 6 Cups of Butternut Squash, so I used it all, added an extra apple(didnt peel) and 2 carrots to balance the increase in squash. Used Sweet Potatos (2) & didnt peel. Substituted Herbamare & water instead of Chicken broth. Used Apple Cider instead of wine and omitted the cream. I also used an impersion blender and left it very chunky. Thank you all who shared comments, I combined many of your changes.

Pretty tasty! Used a sweet potato instead of regular as others suggested. Also a fuji apple since I can't have granny smith ones. 
Also I HIGHLY advise you use 1/8tsp nutmeg and taste it first- nutmeg can REALLY overpower the flavor of a dish easily! I found 1/8tsp was plenty. I added a few dashes of cinnamon and a pinch of cayenne as well- Made for a nice mix of savory, sweet, and spicy! 
I only used 1/4 cup cream, but honestly it would be fine without. I also used dry vermouth in place of white wine (I always do this, it's never let me down) and found it added a nice flavor. I can't have ACV, but I can see how that would be tasty as well instead of wine (but only like a tablespoon or so). My husband typically isn't a fan of pureed soups, but this one he liked!

I followed the recipe with the following exceptions. Used leftover squash steamed last night. Macintosh apple and instant mashed potatoes. Did not have any carrots. Used ginger and nutmeg. Excellent! 12-2015
